question_stem.en: A 35-year-old woman with a history of migraines is evaluated due to a recent increase in headache frequency and severity. She has had no focal weakness, sensory loss, vision changes, or seizures. The patient has no other medical conditions and takes sumatriptan as needed. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Physical examination shows no focal neurological deficits. Neuroimaging reveals a small aneurysm arising from the segment of right internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus. If this patient's aneurysm continues to expand, which of the following findings is most likely to be observed? {{exhibit_1}}
question_stem.zh: 一位有偏头痛病史的 35 岁女性因最近头痛频率和严重程度增加而接受评估。她没有出现局灶性无力、感觉丧失、视力改变或癫痫发作。患者没有其他疾病，并根据需要服用舒马曲坦。她不吸烟、不饮酒，也不使用违禁药物。体格检查未见局灶性神经功能缺损。神经影像学显示，右侧颈内动脉海绵窦段出现小动脉瘤。如果该患者的动脉瘤继续扩大，最有可能观察到以下哪种表现？{{exhibit_1}}

question.en: Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed?
question.zh: 最有可能观察到以下哪种表现？

A.en: Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded

B.en: Inability to contract the right orbicularis oculi muscle
B.zh: 无法收缩右侧眼轮匝肌

C.en: Loss of sensation from anterior two-thirds of the tongue
C.zh: 舌前三分之二区域感觉丧失

D.en: Vision defect affecting the left half of the visual field
D.zh: 影响左半视野的视力缺陷

E.en: Weakness of the right lateral rectus muscle

explanation.en:
This patient has a cavernous carotid aneurysm, which was discovered during an evaluation for a change in headache frequency and severity from past migraines. Small aneurysms of the cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery are typically asymptomatic; however, as they enlarge, they can compress nearby structures and cause a unilateral, throbbing headache and/or cranial nerve deficits.

The abducens nerve (CN VI), which passes through the cavernous sinus next to the internal carotid artery, is the most likely structure to be damaged by an expanding aneurysm. Compression or stretching of the nerve results in ipsilateral lateral rectus weakness, which can cause esotropia (inward eye deviation) and horizontal diplopia (double vision) that is worse when looking toward the side of the lesion.

Other nerves that can be damaged by a cavernous carotid aneurysm include the oculomotor nerve (CN III), trochlear nerve (CN IV), and V1 and V2 branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), all of which run on the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. {{exhibit_2}}

(Choice A) The hypoglossal nerves (CN XII) innervate the genioglossus muscles, which are responsible for tongue protrusion. Injury to the right hypoglossal nerve (most commonly during carotid endarterectomy) would cause ipsilateral genioglossus weakness with deviation of the tongue to the right during protrusion.

(Choice B) Muscles of facial expression, including the orbicularis oculi, are innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII). Damage to the lower motor neurons of the facial nerve (eg, parotid gland tumor, trauma) often results in complete paralysis of ipsilateral facial muscles.

(Choice C) General sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by the lingual nerve (mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve), which, unlike the other 2 divisions of the trigeminal nerve, does not course through the cavernous sinus.

(Choice D) Homonymous hemianopia is a defect in half of the visual field due to a contralateral lesion in the visual pathways posterior to the optic chiasm (eg, optic tract, optic radiations). Cavernous carotid aneurysms can occasionally compress the optic nerve or chiasm, usually resulting in ipsilateral monocular vision loss or a nonspecific decrease in visual acuity rather than homonymous hemianopia.

Educational objective:
An expanding aneurysm in the cavernous portion of the internal carotid artery (ICA) is most likely to initially cause headache and diplopia (ipsilateral lateral rectus weakness) due to compressing or stretching of the abducens nerve (CN VI) as it runs next to the ICA in the cavernous sinus. Other commonly affected nerves include the oculomotor nerve (CN III), trochlear nerve (CN IV), and the V1 and V2 branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). {{exhibit_3}}
explanation.zh:
该患者患有海绵窦内颈动脉动脉瘤，在评估既往偏头痛引起的头痛频率和严重程度变化时发现。颈内动脉海绵窦段的小动脉瘤通常无症状；然而，随着动脉瘤增大，它们会压迫附近的结构，引起单侧搏动性头痛和/或颅神经功能缺损。

外展神经（CN VI）穿过海绵窦，紧邻颈内动脉，是最有可能被扩大的动脉瘤损伤的结构。神经受压或牵拉会导致同侧外直肌无力，可引起内斜视（眼球内偏）和水平复视（重影），向病灶侧看时症状更严重。

其他可能被海绵窦内颈动脉动脉瘤损伤的神经包括动眼神经（CN III）、滑车神经（CN IV）以及三叉神经（CN V）的 V1 和 V2 分支，所有这些神经均走行于海绵窦的侧壁。{{exhibit_2}}

（选项 A）舌下神经（CN XII）支配颏舌肌，负责舌的伸出。右侧舌下神经损伤（最常见于颈动脉内膜切除术期间）会导致同侧颏舌肌无力，伸舌时舌向右偏斜。

（选项 B）面部表情肌，包括眼轮匝肌，由面神经（CN VII）支配。面神经下运动神经元受损（例如，腮腺肿瘤、外伤）通常会导致同侧面部肌肉完全瘫痪。

（选项 C）舌前三分之二区域的一般感觉由舌神经（三叉神经的下颌分支）传导，与三叉神经的其他两个分支不同，舌神经不穿过海绵窦。

（选项 D）同向偏盲是由于视交叉后视路（例如，视束、视放射）的对侧病变导致的视野一半的缺陷。海绵窦内颈动脉动脉瘤偶尔会压迫视神经或视交叉，通常会导致同侧单眼视力丧失或非特异性视敏度下降，而不是同向偏盲。

教学目标：
颈内动脉 (ICA) 海绵窦段的动脉瘤扩张最有可能最初引起头痛和复视（同侧外直肌无力），这是由于外展神经（CN VI）在海绵窦内紧邻 ICA 走行时受到压迫或牵拉。其他常受影响的神经包括动眼神经（CN III）、滑车神经（CN IV）以及三叉神经（CN V）的 V1 和 V2 分支。{{exhibit_3}}

summary.en:
This question tests knowledge of cavernous sinus anatomy and the clinical manifestations of a cavernous carotid aneurysm, specifically the cranial nerve deficits that can arise from compression of structures within the cavernous sinus. The key is to recognize the proximity of the abducens nerve (CN VI) to the internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus. 

To solve this question, recall the anatomical relationships within the cavernous sinus and the order in which cranial nerves are typically affected by an expanding aneurysm. Prioritize the abducens nerve due to its location and the resulting lateral rectus weakness causing diplopia.
summary.zh:
本题考察对海绵窦解剖结构的了解以及海绵窦内颈动脉动脉瘤的临床表现，特别是海绵窦内结构受压引起的颅神经功能缺损。关键是要认识到外展神经（CN VI）与海绵窦内的颈内动脉相邻。

要解决这个问题，请回忆海绵窦内的解剖关系，以及扩张的动脉瘤通常会影响颅神经的顺序。由于外展神经的位置及其引起的外直肌无力导致复视，因此优先考虑外展神经。

tags: Cavernous sinus; Cavernous carotid aneurysm; Abducens nerve; Cranial nerve VI; Diplopia; Lateral rectus weakness; Neurology; Neurosurgery
